Alternate translation: "recovers from her flow of blood" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: is cleansed from her flow of blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: The woman whom other people may touch is spoken of as if she were physically clean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: she will be clean

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of preventing the people from becoming unclean as if it were keeping the people at a safe distance from uncleanness. The abstract noun "uncleanness" can be stated as "unclean." Alternate translation: "This is how you must prevent the people of Israel from becoming unclean" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: This is how you must separate the people of Israel from their uncleanness

contextId.occurrenceNote: People whom other people may not touch and who are not acceptable for God's purposes are spoken of as if they were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: their uncleanness

contextId.occurrenceNote: People whom other people may not touch are spoken of as if they were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: makes him unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: People whom other people may not touch are spoken of as if they were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: an unclean woman

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sinful actions which make people unacceptable to Yahweh are spoken of as if they were physically unclean actions. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: unclean actions

contextId.occurrenceNote: The altar being fit to be used for God's purposes is spoken of as if it were physically clean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to cleanse it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The altar being dedicated to Yahweh is spoken of as if it were physically separated from the sins of the people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: set it apart to Yahweh, away from the unclean actions of the people of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sinful actions which make people unacceptable to Yahweh are spoken of as if they were physically unclean actions. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the unclean actions

contextId.occurrenceNote: People who are acceptable for God's purposes are spoken of as if they were physically clean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to cleanse you ... so you will be clean

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person being excluded from his community is spoken of as if he had been cut off from his people, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. This can be translated in active form. See how you translated this in [Leviticus 7:20](../07/20.md). Alternate translation: "that person may no longer live among his people" or "you must separate that person from his people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: that man must be cut off from among his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people being unfaithful to Yahweh by worshiping false gods is spoken of as if they were acting like a man who betrays his wife by committing adultery. Alternate translation: "for which they are unfaithful to Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for which they act as prostitutes

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person being excluded from his community is spoken of as if he had been cut off from his people, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. This can be translated in active form. See how you translated this in [Leviticus 7:20](../07/20.md). Alternate translation: "that person may no longer live among his people" or "you must separate that person from his people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: that man must be cut off from his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person being excluded from his community is spoken of as if he had been cut off from his people, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. Alternate translation: "I will not permit that person to live among his people any longer" or "I will separate that person from his people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will cut him off from among his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person being excluded from his community is spoken of as if he had been cut off from his people, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "Whoever eats blood may no longer live among his people" or "You must separate from his people anyone who eats blood" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Whoever eats it must be cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: An animal being killed by wild animals is spoken of as if the wild animals tore the animal to pieces. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "that wild animals have killed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: that has been torn by wild animals

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person whom other people may not touch is spoken of as if he were physically unclean and the person whom other people may touch is spoken of as if he were physically clean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he will be unclean ... Then he will be clean

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person's guilt is spoken of as if it were a physical object that the person carries. Here the word "guilt" represents the punishment for that guilt. Alternate translation: "then he is responsible for his own guilt" or "then I will punish him for his sin" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: then he must carry his guilt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Obeying Yahweh's commandments is spoken of as if the commandments were a path on which the person walks. Alternate translation: "so that you conduct your behavior according to them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: so that you walk in them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh forcibly removing the people from the land is spoken of as if the land were a person who vomited the people out. Alternate translation: "I forcibly removed the people from the land, like a person vomits up food" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the land vomited out its inhabitants

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh forcibly removing the people from the land is spoken of as if the land were a person who vomited the people out. See how you translated this metaphor in [Leviticus 18:25](../18/25.md). Alternate translation: "so that I do forcibly remove you from the land ... as I forcibly removed the people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: so that the land does not vomit you up ... as it vomited out the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: People being excluded from the community is spoken of as if they had been cut off from their people, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "the persons ... may no longer live among their people" or "you must separate the persons ... from their people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: the persons ... will be cut off from among their people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Worshiping idols is spoken of as if it were physically turning towards them. Alternate translation: "Do not begin to worship worthless idols" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not turn to worthless idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person's guilt is spoken of as if it were a physical object that the person carries. Here the word "guilt" represents the punishment for that guilt. Alternate translation: "everyone ... is responsible for his own guilt" or "Yahweh will punish everyone ... for his sin" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: everyone ... must carry his own guilt

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person being excluded from his community is spoken of as if he had been cut off from his people, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. This can be translated in active form. See how you translated this in [Leviticus 7:20](../07/20.md). Alternate translation: "that person may no longer live among his people" or "you must separate that person from his people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: that person must be cut off from his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Continually hating a person is spoken of as if it were hating a person in the heart. Alternate translation: "Do not continually hate your brother" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not hate your brother in your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase compares those who are unfaithful to Yahweh to prostitutes. Alternate translation: "who is unfaithful to Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who prostitutes himself in order to play the harlot with Molech

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase compares the unfaithful people to prostitutes. Alternate translation: "by doing that, they seek advice from the spirits rather than from me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: so as to prostitute themselves with them

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person being excluded from his community is spoken of as if he had been cut off from his people, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. This can be translated in active form. See how you translated this idea in [Leviticus 7:20](../07/20.md). Alternate translation: "that person may no longer live among his people" or "you must separate that person from his people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: must be cut off from

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase compares having sex with a woman during her menstrual period to removing the cover off of something that should remain hidden. The fact that this was a shameful thing to do can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: "he has done a shameful thing by uncovering the flow of her blood" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: he has uncovered her flow, the fountain of her blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase describes the land as a vomiting person who needs to reject bad food. Instead of rejecting bad food, the land rejects the people and removes them. See how you translated this metaphor in [Leviticus 18:25](../18/25.md). Alternate translation: "the land to which I am bringing you will not reject you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the land into which I am bringing you to live will not vomit you up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Doing the actions of idol worshipers is spoken of as walking in their ways. Alternate translation: "you must not follow" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You must not walk in

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who is not acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: make himself unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who is not acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: while he is unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: A priest no longer being able to serve Yahweh is spoken of as if that person had been cut off from Yahweh's presence, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "that person will no longer be able to serve as a priest" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: that person must be cut off from before me

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who is acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically clean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: until he is clean

contextId.occurrenceNote: Something that Yahweh has said is unfit to touch or eat is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Whoever touches anything unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who is not acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the priest ... will be unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: "the priest will then be considered clean." A person who is acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically clean. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he will then be clean

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sin is spoken of as if it were an object that people can carry. Possible meanings are 1) they would be responsible for the sin and so become guilty. Alternate translation: "they would be guilty for the sin that they committed" or 2) the word "sin" is a metonym for punishment for the sin that they committed. Alternate translation: "they would receive the punishment because they are guilty" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: cause themselves to carry the sin that would make them guilty

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Lord's pleasure with the aroma represents his pleasure with the person who burns the offering. Alternate translation: "Yahweh will be pleased with you" or "that pleases the Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: producing a sweet aroma for Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being excluded is spoken of as being cut off. See how you translated this idea in [Leviticus 7:20](../07/20.md). Alternate translation: "must be excluded from his people" or "you must separate that person from his people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: must be cut off from his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Suffering for sin is spoken of if a person were to carry his guilt. Alternate translation: "must suffer for his sin" or "must be punished (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: must carry his own guilt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Behaving according to the laws is spoken of as if they were to walk in the laws. Alternate translation: "If you behave according to my laws" or "if you live according to my laws" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: walk in my laws

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of them having many children as if they were trees that bear a lot of fruit. Alternate translation: "cause you to have many children" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: make you fruitful

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking among them represents living with them. Alternate translation: "I will live with you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will walk among you

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of their slavery as if they had to wear a yoke that animals wear in order to do hard work. Breaking the bars of the yoke represents setting them free. Alternate translation: "I have set you free from the hard labor they made you do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I have broken the bars of your yoke

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "terror" represents the things that will cause them to be terrified. Alternate translation: "I will send disasters that will terrify you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will inflict terror on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Using force to cause them not to be proud is spoken of as if he were to break their pride. Alternate translation: "I will punish you and so end the pride that you feel about your power" or "I will punish you so that you will no longer be proud of your power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will break your pride in your power

contextId.occurrenceNote: Working very hard is spoken of as if they were to use all their strength until they had no more strength. The phrase "for nothing" means that they would get nothing from working so hard. Alternate translation: "You will work very hard in vain" or "You will work very hard, but you will not receive anything good from working so hard" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Your strength will be used up for nothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking represents behavior. Walking against God represents opposing him or rebelling against him. Alternate translation: "rebel against me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: walk against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing disasters to happen to the Israelites is spoken of as if he would strike them with blows or hit them. Alternate translation: "I will cause seven times as many disasters to come against you" or "I will punish you seven times more severely" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will bring seven times more blows on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Stealing represents attacking or attacking and dragging them away. Alternate translation: "which will attack your children" or "which will drag your children away" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: which will steal your children

contextId.occurrenceNote: Accepting his correction represents responding rightly to it. In this case responding rightly to it is choosing to obey him. Alternate translation: "you still do not listen to my correction" or "you still do not obey me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you still do not accept my correction

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking represents behavior. Walking in opposition to him means opposing him or fighting against him. Alternate translation: "oppose me" or "fight against me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: walk in opposition to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking represents behavior. Walking in opposition to them means opposing them or fighting against them. Alternate translation: "I also will oppose you" or "I also will fight against you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will also walk in opposition to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Destroying the food that people have stored or stopping people from being able to get it is spoken of as cutting off the supply of food. Alternate translation: "When I destroy the food you have stored" or "When I stop you from being able to get food" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: When I cut off your food supply

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking represents behavior. Walking against someone represents opposing him or fighting against him. Alternate translation: "to oppose me" or "to fight against me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to walk against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking represents behavior. Walking against someone represents opposing him or fighting against him. Alternate translation: "I will oppose you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will walk against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of idols not being alive as if they had been alive and then died. Alternate translation: "your lifeless idols" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the corpses of your idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Normally the Lord's pleasure with the aroma represents his pleasure with those who burn the offering. But in this case, people would burn offerings, but God would not be pleased with them. Alternate translation: "You will burn offerings, but I will not be pleased with you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will not be pleased with the aroma of your offerings

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sending fear into their hearts represents making them afraid. Alternate translation: "I will make you terribly afraid" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will send fear into your hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents opposing them. Alternate translation: "to oppose them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to turn against them

contextId.occurrenceNote: If Yahweh will not accept a certain animal as an offering, the animal is spoken of as if it were physically dirty. It may be unclean because it is a certain kind of animal or because it has a defect. Alternate translation: "is in fact one that Yahweh will not accept" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: is in fact unclean, so that Yahweh will not accept it

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Stand" represents "remain" or "remain the same." Alternate translation: "its value will remain the same" or "its value will be the full amount" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the valuation of it will stand
